title: Structured Task Clarification & Execution Control Framework

nodes.title: Pause Before Action
nodes.body:
Stop before starting execution.

Do not begin work based on assumptions or intuition.
If you cannot clearly explain what "done" means, the task is not ready.

Before moving forward, align on a shared clarification template.
This template defines what "clarified" actually means and acts as a contract for further discussion.

---

TASK CLARIFICATION TEMPLATE (BASE VERSION)

Task Name:
- Concrete and operational, includes an action verb

Goal (WHY?):
- What problem are we solving or what value are we delivering?

Scope (WHAT?):
IN SCOPE:
- What must be included

OUT OF SCOPE:
- What is explicitly excluded

Acceptance Criteria (WHEN IS IT DONE?):
- Observable and testable success conditions

Priority / Deadline:
- Relative priority (high / medium / low)
- Deadline, sprint, or time constraint

Dependencies / Constraints:
- External teams, systems, or limitations

Decision Owner / Point of Contact:
- Who approves outcomes or resolves ambiguity

---

MINIMAL "EMERGENCY" VERSION (WHEN TIME IS LIMITED)

Goal:
- ...

Scope:
- ...

Definition of Done:
- ...

If these three fields cannot be filled, the task is not ready for execution.

Use this template as the reference point for all clarification steps that follow.

nodes.title: Identify the Missing Information
nodes.body:
Use this step as a checklist mapped directly to the clarification template.

Systematically verify whether each required section is sufficiently defined.
Iterate until no meaningful gaps remain.

Checklist areas:
- Goal
- Scope (in scope / out of scope)
- Acceptance Criteria
- Priority & Deadline
- Dependencies & Constraints
- Decision Ownership

Do not proceed until the template can be reasonably filled.

nodes.title: Clarify the Goal
nodes.body:
Define the WHY.

Helpful questions:
- What problem does this task solve?
- What value is delivered if it succeeds?
- Who benefits and how?
- What negative outcome occurs if this is not done?

The goal should fit into one clear sentence.

nodes.title: Clarify the Scope
nodes.body:
Define WHAT is included and excluded.

Helpful questions:
- What must be delivered for this to count as complete?
- What is explicitly not part of this task?
- What common assumptions should be ruled out?

If scope is not written down, it will expand silently.

nodes.title: Clarify Acceptance Criteria
nodes.body:
Define WHEN the task is done.

Helpful questions:
- How will we verify success?
- What conditions must be met for acceptance?
- Who confirms that criteria are satisfied?

Acceptance criteria must remove interpretation.

choices.label: Acceptance criteria clarified – return to checklist

nodes.title: Clarify Priority and Deadline
nodes.body:
Define urgency and importance.

Helpful questions:
- How does this compare to other tasks?
- Is there a fixed deadline or flexible window?
- What happens if this slips?

Unclear priority guarantees conflict later.

choices.label: Priority and deadline clarified – return to checklist

nodes.title: Clarify Decision Ownership
nodes.body:
Define WHO decides.

Helpful questions:
- Who approves the final outcome?
- Who resolves disagreements?
- Who can change requirements mid-way?

Without ownership, every decision is provisional.

choices.label: Decision ownership clarified – return to checklist

nodes.title: Clarify Dependencies and Constraints
nodes.body:
Surface external factors early.

Helpful questions:
- Are other teams or systems involved?
- Are there technical, legal, or process constraints?
- What assumptions depend on others?

Hidden dependencies are delayed failures.

nodes.title: Ask Structured Decision-Forcing Questions
nodes.body:
Use the filled template to ask precise questions.

Your goal is confirmation or explicit change, not discussion.

Examples:
- Is this goal correct?
- Are we explicitly excluding these items?
- Which acceptance criterion is mandatory vs optional?

Precision beats politeness.

nodes.title: Propose Your Own Interpretation
nodes.body:
Create a draft using the clarification template.

The draft should contain:
- Goal (one sentence)
- Scope: in scope / out of scope
- Acceptance criteria (bullet points)
- Assumptions you are making
- Open questions that remain

Present it as a proposal for confirmation.
This shifts the conversation from ambiguity to concrete validation.

nodes.title: Define the First Meaningful Action
nodes.body:
Identify the smallest next step that can be executed without guessing.

The action should reduce uncertainty or validate assumptions.
If it still depends on interpretation, break it down further.

nodes.title: Set a Decision Checkpoint
nodes.body:
Define when and how validation happens.

Specify:
- Timing
- Decision-maker
- Exact question to be answered

Never work long in silence on unclear tasks.

nodes.title: Document Agreements
nodes.body:
Persist the filled template or key conclusions in writing.

Written clarity prevents regression into ambiguity.

nodes.title: Evaluate Red Flags
nodes.body:
Escalate or renegotiate if core elements remain unstable.

This is risk management, not obstruction.

nodes.title: Ready for Controlled Execution
nodes.body:
The task is now structured, validated, and documented.

Execution can proceed with shared understanding and controlled risk.
